title: Mice in Bion-M 1 Space Mission: Training and Selection
chunk_summaries: ["The aim of mice experiments in the Bion-M 1 project was to elucidate cellular and molecular mechanisms, underlying the adaptation of key physiological systems to long-term exposure in microgravity. The principal species for biomedical research in this project was the mouse. This paper presents an overview of the scientific goals, the experimental design and the mouse training/selection program.", "Male C57/BL6 mice group housed in space habitats were flown aboard the Bion-M 1 biosatellite. Mice training included the co-adaptation in housing groups and mice adaptation to paste food diet. After the flight, mice were in good condition for biomedical studies and displayed signs of pronounced disadaptation to Earth's gravity.", "Russian biomedical research in space traditionally has employed dogs, rats, monkeys, and more recently Mongolian gerbils. Unlike more recent space experiments that used female mice, males were flown in the Bion-M 1 mission. Bion missions have contributed comprehensive data on adaptive responses of sensorimotor, cardiovascular, muscle, bone and other systems.", "The mouse has become the most prevalent “mammalian model” in biomedical research. While mice are preferred mammalian models for molecular biology studies, their small size is a debated limitation rather than an advantage for physiological studies. The use of genetically controlled mice offers a means to reduce inter-individual variability and obtain potentially more consistent results.", "Half of the mice died during the course of this mission due to various estimated reasons. To our knowledge, Bion-M 1 is the first study with mice to follow the dynamics of re-adaptation to normal gravity or to assess post-flight in vitro functions. The in vivo measurements in-flight included video recording of mice behavior and continuous recording of arterial pressure during all stages of the flight.", "The set of in vivo measurements was designed to provide data on the effects of microgravity on the physiological systems of interest. To reduce the possibility of inadvertently stressing the mice with numerous post-flight tests, the decision was made to monitor mice in their home cage using an automated data collection system. The program had to be performed with a limited number of animals; thus the use of a repeated measures design.", "These samples were analyzed using morphological (light and electron microscopy, histochemistry and immunohistochemistry), biochemical and a variety of molecular-biology techniques. Functional properties of skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle and resistive arteries samples were evaluated using myography and atomic force microscopy. Mice for in vitro studies were euthanized by cervical dislocation.", "It was decided that the optimal age of mice at launch was 4–5 months, when the males were still young but fully mature. Space environment affects microorganisms by increasing their virulence. It is reasonable to think that even pseudo pathogenic species may increase morbidity during prolonged exposure in space. These considerations underscored the necessity for the use of specific pathogen-free mice.", "A total of 4 experimental groups were used for the flight and ground control experiments. Mice of the space flight group (SF) were exposed to microgravity for 30 days. Ground control (GC) experiment was conducted, after the landing, in the refurbished BOS flight habitats. The corresponding vivarium control ( GCV) mice were housed in the animal facility.", "SF mice were flown aboard the Bion-M 1 satellite for 30 days. After landing mice were examined and transported to Moscow, where animals of the in vitro subgroup were dissected. Ground control experiment replicated the principal stages of the spaceflight experiment. The hardware for mice housing in-flight was an adapted version of the habitats used for rats in the original Bion program.", "A stainless steel feeder (9 ml) was mounted at one end (the “top”) of the cylinder. The food distribution system (except for the feeders) was common to all five habitats in the block. A video camera was installed between the light bulbs; video was recorded 6 times daily (simultaneously with feeding, each session lasted 2 hours)", "Four groups of mice, of 3 mice each, were housed in metabolic chambers (Techniplast, Italy) and fed pelleted food (grinded) or paste food. Body weight, food and water consumption, urine volume and feces weight were monitored daily. Arterial pressure was monitored in sub-groups of mice designated for recovery, using implantable probes and telemetry hardware.", "The body of the transmitter was implanted subcutaneously on the flank, briefly described below. Mice were anaesthetized by an intraperitoneal injection of a solution containing tiletamine/zolazepam (15 mg/kg each) combined with xylazine (3mg/kg) Depth of anesthesia was assessed regularly by hind leg pinch and observation of respiration rate.", "The Open field test was performed in a round, 60 cm arena of black plastic with a grey floor and 40 cm high walls. Mouse behavior was video recorded at 25 fps for 10 minutes under a bright white light (200 Lux) followed by 10 min in darkness (IR light) Videos were analyzed for locomotor activity and other behavioral parameters using EthoVision v. 8.5 (Noldus) Grip force was measured using Grass FT-03 force transducer.", "Mice were trained to direct nosepokes to the side opposite to their initial bias. The number of rewarded responses was limited to 50; each sweetened dry milk pellet weighed 14 mg. To promote learning, mice were maintained at 90% ad lib body weight. Access to food was provided throughout the day from 07:30 until 19:00–20:00.", "Living conditions for animals considered optimal on earth cannot be provided in the confines of a space satellite. Microgravity, apart from purely technical limitations of the housing hardware, may disrupt normal mouse behavior. An inability to express natural behavior is posited as a potential cause of distress in laboratory animals. Male mice are known to have aggressive tendencies.", "Environmental enrichment and daily handling were critically important for successful co-adaptation of mice. In a preliminary experiment, when no environmental enrichment was used, only 50% of mice (out of a sample of 42) successfully co- Adapted to living in groups of three. Shelter with good qualities is salient to mice, and male mice will compete for the resource.", "Mice were handled daily to monitor signs of fighting and body weight. Frequent handling proved critically important to condition and calm mice to some of the tests. Extensive handling and homecage enrichments yielded male mice that were tractable and cooperative during potentially provocative procedures. Mice become extremely active when placed in a fresh cage. In unstable groups mice would fight promptly after a change of bedding.", "When paste food was introduced, water consumption decreased roughly 5 times its original amount; body weight increased by 1.5±0.4 g, and feces weight tripled. Measured urine production in mice fed pasted food diet was 2.4 ml/10 g BW. The mice tolerated with apparent ease telemetry probe implantation. The acute recovery was complete by day 5 post-surgery.", "Tests of corneal, pineal and other simple reflexes, performance on RotaRod, grip strength, running wheel performance, and learning and memory tests revealed no adverse effects of probe implantation. We occasionally noted, slight eyelid drooping. Although this ptosis could be interpreted as indicating compromised brain blood supply, we do not believe this was the case.", "Mice with implanted probes can be easily group-housed with intact mice and display little (if any) differences from mice without surgery. Preliminary training and tests were performed with 42 mice for both the flight (SF) experiment and the corresponding vivarium control (SFV) 26 (62%) and 16 (53%) mice correspondingly fulfilled the inclusion criteria. The flight group of mice was transported to Cosmodrome Baikonur one week before launch.", "The environmental parameters in the biosatellite during the orbital mission, in the climatic chamber during the ground control experiment, and in the animal facility for the VC groups were closely matched and within the acceptable range for the housing of rodents. The climate parameters aboard the satellite were within the designed range throughout the flight. In the flight (SF) experiment 16 out of 45 mice (36%) survived.", "Video from the Bion habitats captured during both light and dark phases of each day of the mission. Video quality was superior in the early phases of the flight and visibility was compromised over time. There was no evidence of fighting, biting, or agonistic behavior in any of the video samples, so we do not believe any of deaths or injuries resulted from aggression among the males.", "The video records clearly showed that the mice spent much time in physical contact (huddling) with one another and, significantly we think, they were grouped against the flat, feeder wall of the cylindrical habitat. We quantified their location within each habitat on select days during the flight; choosing days on which the video segments provided good available visibility.", "Video samples documented that male mice aggregated non-randomly at the feeder wall of the cylindrical habitat. Results obtained in the Bion-M 1 mission should be taken into account in design of new mice habitats for future space missions. In microgravity, the animals assumed a greater range of orientations at the wall and may have more actively inserted their bodies into the recesses.", "Despite the general design has long since proven its efficiency in the previous Bion flights with rats, further development is needed to better adapt it for mice based on this study. The advantage of the habitats design is its ability to support mice without any human interference in relatively long duration missions. This degree of autonomy has not been reached by any other of the existing animal habitats.", "The majority of mice either gained some weight or maintained their pre-flight values. Post-hoc comparisons revealed no differences between the groups before the experiments. The differences in bodyweight between spaceflight, ground control and vivarium control groups were not significant. We consider that this discrepancy is explained by little opportunity for exercise in the relatively small habitats in microgravity.", "Behavior parameters of mice from two vivarium groups, SFV and GCV, were indistinguishable. SF mice displayed reduced activity compared to any of the control groups. Mice housed in habitats (SF and GC) were reluctant to explore the center of the arena. Both SF and GC mice who were housed in relatively small habitats displayed more pronounced thigmotaxis.", "The drastic decrease in activity by SF mice in this test is obviously related to adverse impact of prolonged 30-days spaceflight on the sensorimotor systems of these animals. Because OFT activity is known to decrease with repetitive tests, the repeated testing approach used in this study could potentially obscure the effects of spaceflight.", "The number of control mice (GC, SFV, GCV) for in vitro studies was decreased proportionately to the number of SF animals available. Dissection of SF and SFV mice started 12 hours after landing on May 20 th , 2013. Despite significant loss of animals in flight, the scientific program was not abridged and was implemented in full.", "The Bion-M 1 flight was unique in many ways, particularly the unprecedented duration of an automated mission with living animals. The use of male animals is obviously required for research in male reproduction and their larger size compared to females offered clear advantages. The results of our program presented here demonstrate that group housed male mice need not be excluded a priori , but quite on the contrary, can be successfully employed in space biomedical research.", "Some of the injuries and deaths encountered in this pioneering effort suggest moving parts within the habitat present potential risks. In this space experiment we have, for the first time, introduced implantable telemetry in these small laboratory animals. The good condition of spaceflight mice was the basis for the positive results of both the recovery and tissue sharing studies.", "The authors deeply respect the contribution to the success of this mission made by Evgeniya Yarmanova and Vyacheslav Sedletskiy. The authors are grateful to the staff of Kurchatov NBIC-center for their involvement in this project. The project was supported by the Russian Federal Space Agency and the Russian Academy of Sciences."]
group_summaries: ["Russian biomedical research in space traditionally has employed dogs, rats, monkeys, and more recently Mongolian gerbils. Unlike more recent space experiments that used female mice, males were flown in the Bion-M 1 mission. Half of the mice died during the course of this mission due to various estimated reasons.", "Four groups of mice, of 3 mice each, were housed in metabolic chambers and fed pelleted food (grinded) or paste food. Body weight, food and water consumption, urine volume and feces weight were monitored daily. Arterial pressure was monitored in sub-groups of mice designated for recovery, using implantable probes and telemetry hardware.", "Mice with implanted probes can be easily group-housed with intact mice and display little (if any) differences from mice without surgery. In the flight (SF) experiment 16 out of 45 mice (36%) survived. Video samples documented that male mice aggregated non-randomly at the feeder wall of the cylindrical habitat.", "The Bion-M 1 flight was unique in many ways, particularly the unprecedented duration of an automated flight. The good condition of spaceflight mice was the basis for the positive results of both the recovery and tissue sharing. The authors deeply respect the contribution to the success of this flight made by Vyacheslav Sedletski."]
final_summary: Russian biomedical research in space traditionally has employed dogs, rats, monkeys, and more recently Mongolian gerbils. Unlike more recent space experiments that used female mice, males were flown in the Bion-M 1 mission. Half of the mice died during the course of this mission due to various estimated reasons. In the flight (SF) experiment 16 out of 45 mice (36%) survived. Video samples documented that male mice aggregated non-randomly at the feeder wall of the cylindrical habitat. The good condition of spaceflight mice was the basis for the positive results of both the recovery and tissue sharing.

title: Microgravity Induces Pelvic Bone Loss through Osteoclastic Activity, Osteocytic Osteolysis, and Osteoblastic Cell Cycle Inhibition by CDKN1a/p21
chunk_summaries: ["Official websites use .gov A .gov website belongs to an official U.S. government organization. Secure .gov websites use HTTPS A lock ( Lock Locked padlock icon ) or https:// means you've safely connected to the .gov site. Share sensitive information only on official, secure websites.", "To test this possibility, we exposed 16-week-old female C57BL/6J mice to microgravity for 15-days on the STS-131 space shuttle mission. Analysis of the pelvis by µCT shows decreases in bone volume fraction (BV/TV) of 6.29%, and bone thickness of 11.91%. TRAP-positive osteoclast-covered trabecular bone surfaces also increased in microgravity by 170%.", "On Earth, at 1 g, mechanical loading of mammalian tissues is an important factor in maintaining tissue health and promoting normal regenerative growth. During spaceflight, gravity-generated forces are absent and the mechanical stimulation of tissues is greatly diminished. The reduction in gravity mechano-stimulation may decrease regenerative proliferation and differentiation of tissue-specific adult stem cells. This in turn may have significant health consequences for multiple tissues throughout the body, including bone.", "Short-duration exposure to microgravity rapidly leads to alterations in bone mineral content, cellular dynamics, and gene expression patterns. Increased osteoclast bone resorptive activity has been documented within the first several days of spaceflight. Of potentially more importance to long duration missions in microgravity is the reported reduction of bone formation by osteoblasts in growing rats. This bone formation arrest may translate into an impairment of regenerative mechanisms.", "P53 levels are reported to increase in the muscle of hindlimb-unloaded animals. The CDKN1a/p21 knockout mouse has a viable phenotype with strong tissue regenerative abilities, such as limb re-growth. This phenotype suggests up-regulation in microgravity could explain broad regenerative deficits in space.", "Osteocytic osteolysis was shown to be present in lactating mice but not activated in animals that were hindlimb unloaded for 4 weeks. We hypothesized that decreases in bone formation during spaceflight may be mediated by an inability of cells in osteogenic lineages to proliferate and differentiate normally.", "The average weight loss of space-flown mice was 2.0 g, significantly lower than pre-flight values. Flight habitats showed utilization of resources on average of 10% less food, and 24% less water than synchronous ground controls. No difference was observed in bone mineral density and total bone volumes measured (TV and BV)", "Analysis of cross-sectional slices revealed that the flight samples had similar widths at two measured points (b/c ratio of 1.09, Fig. 1D , Table 2 ), and a mean bend angle of 167° (deviating 13° from linear, or less bent) Flight animals exhibited a higher percentage of slices in the 0.007–0.128 mm range compared to ground controls. The shift in thickness distribution to the left in flight animals indicates an overall decrease in cross-sections throughout the ischium.", "No difference was found in bulk density of cortical bone between the flight and ground controls. Flight samples exhibited an enlargement in lacunae of 17% in cross sectional area. We also measured canalicular diameters in a 15 µm perilacunar region and found an increase of 6% in spaceflight samples.", "We found a 197% increase in osteoclast numbers in the bone surface of the trabecular region below the femoral head growth plate of flight samples. The bone surface covered by osteoclasts also increased by 154% in microgravity. Pyknotic nuclei were occasionally present in tissue surrounding bone, but were non-detectable in osteocytes. However, bulk density analysis showed no statistical difference between flight and ground control animals.", "Analysis of osteoclastic activity in the trabecular region below the femoral head of the femur showed an increase in osteoclast numbers in the bone surface of the growth plate of flight samples compared to ground controls. The number of TRAP-positive osteocytes in cortical bone was increased in response to spaceflight. However, we found no differences in the number of empty lacunae between flight and ground control samples.", "RT-PCR analysis of ilium revealed significant up-regulation of matrix degradation molecules MMP1a, MMP3, and MMP10 in flight samples compared to ground controls. Immunohistochemical analysis localized over-expression of MMP 10 to osteocytes in the shaft of the proximal femur in flight.", "RT-PCR analysis of revealed altered expression levels of key genes involved in osteogenic growth and proliferation including growth factors, Bmp4 and Tgfβ2, and transcription factors Vdr and Sox9. Analysis of key mitogenic signal transduction pathways revealed alterations in gene expression of the MAPK pathway.", "Several genes associated with cell cycle regulation were also altered in flight samples. RT-PCR analysis revealed significant alterations in many cell cycle molecules including a 3.31 fold up-regulation of p21 and down- regulation of p53. Immunohistochemical analysis localized this overexpression of p 21 to osteoblasts along the periosteal surface of the proximal femur.", "Muscle fibers surrounding the femur contained strongly positive p21 staining nuclei in spaceflight but not ground control samples. No significant staining was found in most sections from both flight and ground controls’, indicating that p53 was not strongly expressed. No statistically significant alterations in Pi3K subunits were noted except a small change in the alpha polypeptide of the catalytic subunit ofPi3K.", "After exposure to microgravity, the NF-κB inhibitor, IκBα, exhibited a significant increase in expression. Several downstream effectors of these signaling pathways were also altered in response to spaceflight, including Rps6kb1 and Eif4ebp1. Analysis of NFκB transcriptional target genes involved in cell adhesion, regulation of apoptosis and growth factors were found to be down-regulated.", "Osteoclastic activity, osteogenic cell cycle arrest and increased osteocytic osteolysis may also contribute to bone loss in space. We first characterized standard bone mineral and structural parameters following spaceflight to establish the magnitude of bone loss. Our results confirm the ischium portion of the pelvis lost 6.3% bone volume fraction and 11.9% in bone thickness.", "The geometry of the ischium in flight samples is also altered with a wider marrow cavity conformation than ground controls. The quadratus femoris plays an important “antigravity” role in maintaining a neutral hind-limb posture and can atrophy in microgravity. Osteocytes are the most abundant cell type in bone and are thought to play a role in spaceflight-induced bone loss.", "The number of TRAP-positive osteocytes in flight samples was increased compared to ground controls, with no apparent differences in cell death or lacunar emptying. It is currently debated whether osteocytes contribute to bone remodeling and loss during spaceflight. However, our results support a role for microgravity-induced osteocytic osteolysis.", "Remarkably we also found that osteocytes embedded within the cortical bone of the proximal femur were strongly MMP10 positive in flight samples but not in ground controls. ECM proteinases play a critical role in normal pericellular matrix remodeling following environmental stimuli. We also hypothesized that bone loss in space may be mediated by intracellular signaling cascades that result in activation of p53 and p21 during osteogenesis.", "Mice null for p53 exhibit extensive blood tumors and an osteopetrotic bone phenotype. Previous studies have shown that p53 levels are increased in the muscle of animals exposed to spaceflight. In contrast to these findings we determined that mRNA expression levels of p53 in marrow free bone tissue was down-regulated.", "In contrast to p53, expression of CDKN1a/p21, a cell cycle arrest mediator, was up-regulated during spaceflight. This may cause an inhibition of osteogenesis and bone formation. MRL mice, which regenerate cartilage, skin, hair follicles, and myocardium with high fidelity, also lack p21 expression.", "Elevated levels of ROS can result in increased lipid peroxidation and decreased levels of antioxidants. Various other genes associated with cell cycle regulation were altered in response to spaceflight. The expression of these genes without increased cellular indications of apoptosis could be related to the survival-promoting function of p21 when the cell cycle is arrested.", "Growth factor binding can have significant impacts on intracellular signaling cascades and gene expression. We found message expression reductions in TGF-β2; FGF1 and 3; BMP4; Egr1; and Csf3. We also found decreases in the expression levels of Bmp4 message, which is one of the most potent inducers of bone formation.", "Myod1 is also broadly expressed in other tissues and down-regulation of Myod1 message is suggestive of decreased p21-mediated cell differentiation. Twist 1, known to be involved in differentiation by inhibiting DNA binding by Myod 1 and transactivation by Mef2, was up-regulated. Vitamin D receptor and Sox9, two transcription factors involved in osteogenesis, were also differentially expressed in spaceflight.", "Vitamin D has been shown to modulate NFκB activity in multiple cell types, which suggests a role for the Vitamin D receptor in regulation of the NFkkB pathway. The MAP kinase-ERK pathway is also known to activate the transcription factor Sox9, which is a regulatory factor required for chondrocyte differentiation. Sox9 is important for extracellular matrix production.", "The findings on CDKN1a/p21 up-regulation in microgravity have the potential to become a major concern for tissue regenerative health in long-duration spaceflight. Female, 16-week-old C57BL/6J mice were subjected to 15-days of spaceflight on board the space shuttle Discovery during the STS-131 mission.", "Animals were not acclimated to habitats prior to flight. Food and water consumption of each group was measured upon recovery and averaged per mouse per day. Animals were euthanized approximately 2 h after landing using isoflurane anesthesia followed by thoracotomy. The pelvis and femur were dissected and the soft tissue was removed from the bones.", "Of the original 8 samples in each group, both flight and ground control had one sample that was fractured during the dissection rendering it unsuitable for the µCT analysis. Each ischium with soft tissue still intact was mounted vertically into a low-x-ray density Styrofoam holder, wrapped with Press-n-Seal film to prevent drying, and scanned in air. Images were reconstructed into a stack of 2D cross-sectional slices using NRecon volumetric reconstruction software (Skyscan v1.6.3.2)", "Ischia from seven ground control and eight spaceflight mice were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde and stored in PBS. X-ray attenuation images were acquired at 5.4 keV energy with 40 nm resolution. Analysis was performed on similarly oriented transverse sections of cortical bone from mouse ischia.", "Triplicate 0° angle images of each sample for osteocyte lacunar and canalicular analysis were obtained. Images at 90°, were exposed for 8 s with a beam intensity of 1, and used to measure section thickness. For calibration of mineral density to an X-ray attenuation curve, we used chlorapatite crystals standards and methods previously described.", "Decalcified bones were dehydrated in a graded ethanol series and embedded in paraffin in preparation for immunohistochemical analysis. Longitudinal sections of 7 μm thickness were prepared and stained for tartrate resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) using an Acid Phosphatase Leukocyte Kit (Sigma-Aldrich, Catalog #387A-1KT) according to the manufacturer protocol. Images were acquired immediately after staining at magnifications of 20× and 40×.", "Total RNA was isolated from both RNAlater-fixed pelvic ilia (flushed of bone marrow) from spaceflight and ground control animals. Gene expression was analyzed using Qiagen Pathway-Focused Mouse qPCR Arrays. We examined genes involved in osteogenesis, extracellular matrix, ubiquitination, and the p53, Pi3K, NFκB, and MAP Kinase, signaling pathways in bone tissue.", "Each array consisted of primer sets for 84 pathway-focused genes of interest, five reference genes (Gusb, Hprt1, Hsp90ab1, Gapdh, and Actb), one genomic DNA contamination control, three positive PCR controls and three positive reverse transcription controls. One μg of total RNA per sample was reverse transcribed to cDNA using RT 2 First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (SABiosciences, Catalog #330401) according to manufacturer’s protocol.", "The following primary polyclonal antibodies were used in the immunohistocehmical analysis. Peroxidase conjugated donkey anti-rabbit IgG was used as the secondary antibody. For osteocyte nuclear localization, we used Hoechst 33342 staining on deparaffinized sections of the right-proximal femur prepared as described above. Lacunae with and without stained nuclei, and nuclear pyknotic morphology were used to quantify osteocyte apoptosis.", "The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript. Articles from PLoS ONE are provided here courtesy of the National Library of Medicine 8600 Rockville Pike Bethesda, MD 20894. For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or see www.samaritans.org."]
group_summaries: ["The average weight loss of space-flown mice was 2.0 g, significantly lower than pre-flight values. Flight habitats showed utilization of resources on average of 10% less food, and 24% less water than synchronous ground controls. No difference was observed in bone mineral density and total bone volumes measured (TV and BV)", "Osteoclastic activity, osteogenic cell cycle arrest and increased osteocytic osteolysis may also contribute to bone loss in space. The number of TRAP-positive osteocytes in flight samples was increased compared to ground controls, with no apparent differences in cell death or lacunar emptying. Osteocytes are the most abundant cell type in bone and are thought to play a role in spaceflight-induced bone loss.", "Mice null for p53 exhibit extensive blood tumors and an osteopetrotic bone phenotype. Expression of CDKN1a/p21, a cell cycle arrest mediator, was up-regulated during spaceflight. Vitamin D receptor and Sox9, two transcription factors involved in osteogenesis, were also differentially expressed in space flight.", "The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript. We examined genes involved in osteogenesis, extracellular matrix, ubiquitination, and the p53, Pi3K, NFκB, and MAP Kinase, signaling pathways in bone tissue."]
final_summary: The average weight loss of space-flown mice was 2.0 g, significantly lower than pre-flight values. Flight habitats showed utilization of resources on average of 10% less food, and 24% less water than synchronous ground controls. No difference was observed in bone mineral density and total bone volumes measured. Expression of CDKN1a/p21, a cell cycle arrest mediator, was up-regulated during spaceflight. Vitamin D receptor and Sox9, two transcription factors involved in osteogenesis, were also differentially expressed in space flight. The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript.

title: Microgravity and Cellular Biology: Insights into Cellular Responses and Implications for Human Health
chunk_summaries: ["Microgravity significantly impacts the immune system by disrupting key mechanisms. In cancer biology, it promotes the formation of spheroids in cancer stem cells and thyroid cancer cells. Microgravity enhances tissue regeneration by modulating critical pathways, including Hippo and PI3K-Akt. Share sensitive information only on official, secure websites.", "At the organ level, microgravity induces notable changes in hepatic metabolism, endothelial function, and bone mechanotransduction. Cardiomyocytes cultured under microgravity exhibit enhanced mitochondrial biogenesis, improved calcium handling, and advanced structural maturation. These findings underscore the dual implications of microgravity for space medicine and terrestrial health.", "Under microgravity conditions, mechanical forces that influence cell structure and function undergo significant alterations. These changes in turn affect critical cellular processes, including proliferation, differentiation, communication, and survival. Historically, research on microgravity has been conducted aboard space stations and on suborbital platforms. More recently, terrestrial laboratories have adopted advanced technologies, such as rotating bioreactors, to simulate microgravity.", "Microgravity significantly impacts the immune system, compromising the development, function, and response of immune cells. Hematopoietic stem cells, essential for generating immune cells, show impaired differentiation into macrophages, critical for infection control. Microgravity weakens the body’s defenses in space environments.", "An imbalance between M1 (pro-inflammatory) and M2 (anti-inflammatory and repair) macrophages disrupts the immune system’s ability to handle infections and repair tissues. Dendritic cells, pivotal in T lymphocyte activation via antigen presentation, are also adversely affected. Neutrophils exhibit increased numbers in microgravity but with reduced functionality.", "T cell activation, proliferation, and cytokine production are also suppressed, accompanied by decreased expression of IL-2R. At the molecular level, microgravity disrupts critical signaling pathways, including the RAS-RAF-MEK-ERK cascade and the NF-κB pathway. These findings highlight the widespread and multifaceted effects of microgravity on immune system function.", "Microgravity disrupts critical signaling pathways, including RAS, ERK, and NF-κB. The RAS pathway, which governs cell proliferation and survival, shows reduced activity under microgravity. ERK undergoes alterations that hinder the activation and specialization of macrophages and lymphocytes. These processes promote apoptosis in various cancer cell types.", "Microgravity-induced changes include decreased cell adhesion and altered gene expression. Study of cancer stem cells (CSCs) under simulated microgravity conditions provides critical insights into their behavior in extreme environments. CSCs are characterized by their self-renewal and differentiation capabilities, which contribute to tumor heterogeneity, treatment resistance, and metastasis.", "Microgravity has been shown to increase apoptosis, or programmed cell death, in cancer cells. It also alters CSC properties, leading to a decrease in pluripotency markers and an increase in differentiation. Microgravity induces structural changes in the cytoskeleton and extracellular matrix, which may influence tumor progression.", "Microgravity induces the formation of multicellular spheroids (MCS), which mimic solid tumors and exhibit increased resistance to chemotherapy and radiation. Reduced gravity downregulates adhesion proteins (e.g., E-cadherin, vinculin, paxillin), weakening cell–cell interactions and potentially enhancing metastatic potential. Simulated microgravity, using devices like the rotating wall bioreactor (RWV) and random positioning machine (RPM), replicates certain effects of real microgravity.", "Microgravity alters extracellular vesicle (EV) protein and microRNA content. The mechanosensitive channel ELKIN1 plays a crucial role in cellular responses to microgravity. In microgravity, adherent thyroid cancer cells lose their adhesion properties and organize into multicellular spheroids. Microgravity reduces tumor cell adhesion and invasion, offering potential therapeutic benefits.", "These structures closely resemble the physiological characteristics of tumors in vivo, making them ideal models for studying metastasis and evaluating novel targeted therapies. Microgravity also affects fundamental cellular processes, including apoptosis, cytoskeletal organization, and extracellular matrix dynamics. follicular thyroid cancer cells exposed to microgravity have demonstrated a tendency to adopt a less malignant phenotype. The findings from these studies have the potential to revolutionize traditional oncology research approaches.", "Reduced production of interleukin-6 (IL-6), a cytokine crucial for the inflammatory response, further compromises immune functionality and vascular repair capacity. Microgravity stimulates the synthesis of nitric oxide, a critical mediator for blood vessel dilation and angiogenesis. In one study, human umbilical vein endothelial cells were exposed to simulated microgravity for up to 72 h using an RPM.", "Microgravity alters hepatic metabolism, leading to increased lipotoxicity and elevated angiopoietin levels. Intestinal homeostasis is also affected, with observed dysbiosis, endotoxemia and altered bile acid content. Microvascular endothelial cells exhibit inhibited proliferation, decreased IL-6 production, and increased nitric oxide (NO) production.", "Microgravity induces significant bone mass loss, accompanied by a reduction in actin filaments and decreased cell stiffness in osteoblasts. Kidney cells experience metabolic alterations, including reduced oxidative phosphorylation and fatty acid oxidation. Reproductive cells are also impacted, with evidence of reduced egg quality, the loss of polarization in granulosa cells, and a decrease in microvilli.", "Microgravity profoundly impacts the metabolism and functionality of various organs, particularly the liver. In a 42-day head-down bed rest model simulating microgravity, rhesus macaques developed mild liver lesions, fat vacuole accumulation, and inflammatory cell infiltration. These hepatic changes were accompanied by a marked increase in plasma levels of angiopoietin-like 3 (ANGPTL3), a key biomarker associated with metabolic disorders and lipid dysregulation.", "The effects of microgravity on liver function and metabolic homeostasis carry significant implications for space medicine. Astronauts who spend prolonged periods in space experience accelerated bone mass loss. The International Space Station (ISS) is an ideal platform for studying the mechanisms underlying osteoporosis in zero-gravity conditions.", "Microgravity decreases cell stiffness and reduces the levels of filamentous actin. These structural and cytoskeletal alterations highlight disruptions in mechanotransduction, the process through which cells sense and respond to mechanical stimuli. Without the constant gravitational forces present on Earth, osteoblasts lose the ability to maintain their tensional structure and perform optimally.", "Microgravity disrupts mechanical signaling pathways critical for cellular regulation and bone homeostasis. Mechanotransduction is a crucial process by which cells sense and respond to mechanical stimuli. Under microgravity, diminished activity of YAP/TAZ leads to varying outcomes in different cancers. Compressive pressure partially restored YAP expression and increased pSMAD1/5/9 levels.", "A recent study investigated the effects of microgravity on the cellular ability to metabolize vitamin D and respond to human serum. The findings revealed that short-term exposure to microgravity does not significantly alter essential biochemical pathways in renal cells. Surprisingly, no significant differences in vitamin D metabolism were observed between microgravity and terrestrial conditions.", "These findings imply that kidney cells, when exposed to human serum, redirect their metabolism toward a proliferation-focused strategy. Concurrently, significant changes in the extracellular environment were observed, indicative of tissue remodeling. The implications of these discoveries are significant for both space exploration and terrestrial medicine.", "Simulated microgravity has provided valuable insights into how this unique environment impacts egg quality and ovarian follicle development. Ovarian follicles rely on intricate interactions between granulosa cells and the egg to ensure proper maturation. The specific effects of microgravity on these interactions and the overall evolution of follicles have only recently begun to be understood.", "Further analysis of the eggs highlighted deficiencies in the distribution and density of cortical granules, structures vital for maturation. There was a notable reduction in the number of eggs capable of releasing the first polar body, a critical process in egg development. Another key finding was the loss of polarity in granulosa cells, which inhibited the formation of cellular projections.", "These findings suggest that microgravity stimulates mitochondrial formation, improving the cells’ capacity to generate ATP, the primary energy source for cardiac function. Simulated microgravity also positively affects the structural properties of cardiomyocytes. These observations highlight the potential of microgravity to promote metabolic maturation, rendering them more functional.", "These structural enhancements bring cardiomyocytes cultured in microgravity closer to the characteristics of fully functional human cardiac cells. The duration of exposure to microgravity plays a pivotal role in maximizing these benefits. Recent studies suggest that a 7-day exposure period is optimal for promoting significant improvements inCardiomyocyte maturation. Prolonged exposures of 14 days did not yield additional benefits.", "One of the most notable pathways affected is the Hippo pathway, which plays a central role in cell proliferation and tissue damage response. Under microgravity conditions, this pathway is temporarily deactivated. These effects have shown particular promise in regenerating organs such as the heart, with potential applications extending to other tissues. The replication of microgravity effects in terrestrial simulations opens new possibilities for exploring therapeutic treatments based on this phenomenon.", "Microgravity influences hematopoietic stem cell differentiation by activating specific genes and pathways. Cells cultured under simulated microgravity using an RPM have shown significant alterations. Simulated microgravity significantly enhances the differentiation of human pluripotent stem cells. It offers a promising avenue for regenerative medicine and cell therapies.", "Under microgravity conditions, hematopoietic stem cells demonstrate more efficient induction of endothelial hemogenic progenitors. Transcriptomic analyses have identified the differential activation of thousands of genes involved in hematoiesis. These gene expression patterns suggest that microgravity creates a favorable environment for optimizing hematopsies.", "Microgravity also enhances three-dimensional cellular organization, improving interactions between cells and their microenvironment. These interactions are vital for forming hematopoietic niches that replicate physiological conditions more accurately. Pluripotent stem cells exhibit enhanced differentiation potential, increased proliferation, and improved structural organization under microgravity.", "On a physiological level, microgravity-induced metabolic adjustments enhance responsiveness to hypoxic stimuli, promoting hematopoietic maturation. Microgravity significantly influences cell proliferation and functionality, representing a transformative advancement for biomedical research and regenerative medicine. In studies with pancreatic islets and neural crest stem cells, exposure to microgravity notably enhanced cell proliferation.", "Microgravity appears to modulate key signaling pathways, such as PI3K-Akt and mTOR, which regulate cell survival, proliferation, and metabolism. Microgravity offers a unique environment that enhances cell proliferation, viability, and functionality in 3D models. This environment not only promotes cell growth but also improves the functional quality of cells.", "Microgravity alters extracellular nutrient transport and activates molecular pathways that enhance bacterial virulence. A key factor is low fluid shear, a physical stimulus that mimics microgravity environments. Microgravity also influences the transport of oxygen and phosphates due to the absence of convection, replicating conditions similar to those in human infections.", "Microgravity significantly influences a wide array of biological processes, including immune responses, cell proliferation, and tissue regeneration. This unique environment disrupts key mechanisms such as mitochondrial biogenesis, liver metabolism, intestinal homeostasis, and stem cell differentiation. Understanding the regulatory mechanisms involving Hfq could provide insights into mitigating the risks of pathogen virulence during prolonged space missions.", "Advances in understanding the effects of microgravity on stem cells, T cells, and immune function have created new opportunities for therapeutic innovations. Alterations in cellular biology under microgravity conditions have been shown to affect diseases such as cancer, osteoporosis, kidney dysfunction, and infertility. Changes observed in endothelial cell behavior and multi-organ homeostasis highlight microgravity’s potential to revolutionize regenerative medicine.", "Microgravity alters gene expression, cell signaling, and mitochondrial function. In the immune system, microgravity reduces T cell activity and suppresses immune responses. These effects highlight the necessity of mitigating immune dysfunction during space travel. Microgravity research has led to technological and medical breakthroughs with applications beyond space exploration.", "Microgravity presents a unique and multifaceted challenge for human biology. This environment disrupts key biological functions such as immune activity, cell differentiation, tissue regeneration, and mitochondrial biogenesis. Emerging research has highlighted the diverse effects of microgravity. These findings underscore the need for further investigation into how microgravity influences disease mechanisms and treatment responses.", "The ability of microgravity to induce unique biological changes offers unparalleled opportunities to innovate in regenerative medicine, cancer treatment, and the management of immune dysfunctions. By leveraging microgravity as a research platform, medicine and biotechnology stand to gain transformative insights and novel applications. This research received no external funding.", "This section collects any data citations, data availability statements, or supplementary materials included in this article. Articles from International Journal of Molecular Sciences are provided here courtesy of Multidisciplinary Digital Publishing Institute (MDPI) MDPI and/or the editor(s) disclaim responsibility for any injury to people or property resulting from any ideas, methods, instructions or products."]
group_summaries: ["Microgravity significantly impacts the immune system by disrupting key mechanisms. In cancer biology, it promotes the formation of spheroids in cancer stem cells and thyroid cancer cells. Simulated microgravity, using devices like the rotating wall bioreactor (RWV) and random positioning machine (RPM), replicates certain effects of real microgravity.", "Microgravity alters extracellular vesicle (EV) protein and microRNA content. Under microgravity, diminished activity of YAP/TAZ leads to varying outcomes in different cancers. Astronauts who spend prolonged periods in space experience accelerated bone mass loss. The International Space Station is an ideal platform for studying the mechanisms underlying osteoporosis in zero-gravity conditions.", "Simulated microgravity has provided valuable insights into how this unique environment impacts egg quality and ovarian follicle development. Microgravity significantly influences cell proliferation and functionality, representing a transformative advancement for biomedical research and regenerative medicine. The replication of microgravity effects in terrestrial simulations opens new possibilities for exploring therapeutic treatments based on this phenomenon.", "Microgravity offers a unique environment that enhances cell proliferation, viability, and functionality in 3D models. Alterations in cellular biology under microgravity conditions have been shown to affect diseases such as cancer, osteoporosis, kidney dysfunction, and infertility. Changes observed in endothelial cell behavior and multi-organ homeostasis highlight microgravity’s potential to revolutionize regenerative medicine."]
final_summary: Microgravity significantly impacts the immune system by disrupting key mechanisms. In cancer biology, it promotes the formation of spheroids in cancer stem cells and thyroid cancer cells. Alterations in cellular biology under microgravity conditions have been shown to affect diseases such as cancer, osteoporosis, kidney dysfunction, and infertility. Simulated microgravity has provided valuable insights into how this unique environment impacts egg quality and ovarian follicle development. Changes observed in endothelial cell behavior and multi-organ homeostasis highlight microgravity’s potential to revolutionize regenerative medicine. The replication of microgravity effects in terrestrial simulations opens new possibilities for exploring therapeutic treatments based on this phenomenon.
